It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The extra sheet of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire for pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or writing extra sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1942, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: JOHN RONALD STANDEN
2. Your address: 1222 PANDORA AVE., VICTORIA, B.C.
3. Date: February 19th, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   MINESING, ONTARIO, CANADA
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   WILLIAM JOHN STANDEN
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   April 1899
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.)
   I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

In the fall of 1898 we purchased land near the townsite of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. We moved there in 1898 and in 1899 we built our house and started farming. We had a good harvest in 1899 and 1900 and a home.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

In the fall of 1898 we purchased land near the townsite of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. We moved there in 1898 and in 1899 we built our house and started farming. We had a good harvest in 1899 and 1900 and a home.

11. Did you have any difficulties in settling? How did you overcome them?

We had a hard time at first because of the harsh weather conditions. However, we persevered and eventually became successful farmers.

19. How many families moved to Canada in 1856 and 1865 and arrived in Weyburn? Six families moved to Weyburn in 1856 and five families moved there in 1865.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought that was a good idea - Aunt was looking for a quiet place and I didn't have a job.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other people)? Yes, we traveled with a group of friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We used a horse-drawn carriage.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other exciting events).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. There did you settle or take up land? We settled in Assiniboia.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Our family came from Ontario, then back to Canada for a year. We then came back to Ontario on the Regina - Brandon line. The railway was graded last fall.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? We were farmers with a housekeeper and 5 acres until we were married. Then we moved to a homestead near Weyburn. After that, we moved to Obago Bash.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Every 3 weeks, usually.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband, or wife along with the date:

May 8, 1917

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

My brother and my mother, and my aunt's husband came to Kindersley Park, and my uncle's family came to Kindersley Park, and my aunt's family came to Kindersley Park, and my uncle's family came to Kindersley Park.

22. Tell when they came and where they settled.

My younger brother moved there in 1907 and my wife's brother arrived in 1907.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Our food was very scarce during the first year, but we had enough to eat. We had no meat, but our potatoes were very good and we had plenty of fish. The weather was very cold and we had to build a fire and cook our food outside. We also had to get wood for fuel and heat our homes.

24. What was the most difficult part of your life in the early days?

The most difficult part of our lives was getting enough food to eat and keeping warm during the winter months.

25. Did you travel about much in these early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, I traveled quite a bit. I visited friends and attended church regularly.

26. What was the most important thing you learned from your experiences?

The most important thing I learned was to be resourceful and to work hard to provide for my family.

27. What do you think has changed since then?

Since then, technology has improved and transportation has become easier.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

I had my young family left back in 1913 as I was anxious to live in a milder climate. We came to British Columbia via Kelowna in the Okanagan Valley and engaged in fruit farming. We stayed there 8 years when we came to Victoria to retire from active work at the age of 76.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I and my neighbors, Mrs. W. Gibson, formed the West Weyburn School District. I was chairman and secretary but do not recall any details. When we moved to Orange in 1905 I held the same positions there, where the village and surrounding district built their first school and I was a member in having a windbreak planted surrounding the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.
